course.subject: MGMT
course.name: Traps and Pitfalls in Judgment and Decision Making
course.description: Decision making is a central human activity, but how good are we at it? Scientific evidence suggests that our decisions are often biased and flawed, resulting in disappointing or even disastrous outcomes. This course draws upon contemporary research in psychology and other social sciences to better understand how it is that people make decisions, and why those decisions are often made badly. The course will emphasize a theoretical understanding of human decision making, as well as a comprehension of the real world implications of our mistakes both for us and for our society, and what, if anything, can be done about it.

reviews.title: A fun management course with a hint of psychology
reviews.comment_content:
Unexpected content as the course involves a bit of psychology, but presented in an enjoyable way
L1: Intro
L2: Human recognition
L3: Sensation and perception
L4 & L5: Memory
L6: Attention
L7: Emotion
L8: Anchoring
L9: Decoy effect
L10: Joint-separate preference reversal
L11: Overconfidence
L12: Hindsight bias
L13: Diversification bias
reviews.comment_teaching: Carmen is one of the best profs I have met, she is very helpful by giving lots of honest feedbacks, also replying emails quickly which obviously helps a lot. She will arrange a revision session before each exam to answer students' question about exam contents. A project consultation session is also arranged for each project group to make sure their topics are related and relevant to the course. Every lecture will have small experiments which engage students to participate, the class atmosphere was really great!!
reviews.comment_grading:
The course basically is graded based on:
Exam 1 & 2 (~60% combined)
Project report presentation (30%)
Participation (~10%)
Both my exams were just under the mean, I was at the mean for the project report and presentation, and I got high marks in participation. In the end I got B range, which is surprising as I thought I would get C range in a SBM course (yes, I'm from SENG).
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload (listed in the Grading section on the left) was decent for a 3-credit course for me.

Its technically not a midterm and final exam because they were a bit earlier than the usual midterm/ final period. Obviously you have to pay attention to the examples and experiments in lectures to get high score in exams. And the exams were all MC questions.

For the presentation, as long as you get good teammates (not freeriders) it honestly wasn't a lot of work to do, in fact it was quite fun throughout the project period.

As for the participation part, you just need to answer Carmen's questions in lectures (best to answer in every lecture) and also ask questions to other groups during their presentation, then you should get most if not full mark here.

reviews.author: BlasterBlade
reviews.title: If you like psychology, then this is great (decision science, etc)
reviews.comment_content:
The content is not super hard, mainly talks about basic biases that is super relatable in our daily lives.

I attached the course introduction slide, take a look if you are interested in this course, it provides an overview for the course

If you like National Geographic Brain Games TV shows, you'll like this one.

COURSE OBJECTIVES  
On completion of this course, you should be able to:
1. Describe major limits of human cognition that cause errors in judgment and decision making.  
2. Describe major biases in judgment and decision making, and explain the psychological mechanisms
underlying those biases.
3. Discuss the real world implications of our judgment and decision biases for us and for our society,
and suggest what can be done to steer people toward better decisions.  
This course also provides an opportunity for you to:  
4. Develop skills for effective teamwork.
5. Develop skills for communicating ideas persuasively and professionally.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Carmen brings lots of good energy to the atmosphere. She is really kind and provide good consultation feedback.

She also incorporated many examples that is relatable and frequently use funny video to show the biases in real life experiment.

I would say the grading will depends mostly on your exam performance as she gives relatively good score for most of the group projects

reviews.comment_workload:
Besides the usual survey to mark your attendance, group project ,there is a mid term and final exam which both consist of Multiple Choice Question.

You can just read briefly the material to study for the exam as she allows you to bring hardcopy of the lecture powerpoint slides. The exam question is mainly just a experimental behavioural question.

So, the workload is not that high for the exam, while for the group project, it is really depend on your team member.. so be sure to pick a good teammates. But overall the group project is nothing to hardcore, just basic stuff.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was easy to understand. Prof. Ng liked to make use of the results from in-class surveys to support the fact that the biases clearly exist without us realizing.

Although she had a rather local accent, I think international students wouldn't have much of a struggle when attending class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was generally fine.

The examination format was slightly different from normal exams (not sure if it's common in business stream though since I'm under SENG). As long as the answer is within a suggested range, it'll be considered correct.

I had trouble adapting to it at first so...

Exam1: 37.5/70 (mean=52.7; sd=10.5)
Exam2:    70/70 (mean=54.5; sd=10.3)
Project:  73/100 (mean=75.4; sd=5.8)
Overall grade was B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Almost no workload at all. Other than the attendance being taken through in-class surveys (every class after add/drop), and the iPRS voting during the presentation period (towards the end of the semester), I wouldn't think it's too much to handle.

There will be a group project which you'll have to present in front of the class and a report to hand in a week later. You'll have a consultation meeting with Prof. Ng where she'll help guide you through and make sure you're on the right path so the project was pretty manageable(given you have responsible teammates).

reviews.author: whoDis
reviews.title: MGMT 1130
reviews.comment_content:
This is one of the most intriguing courses I took at HKUST so far. Topics covered span the different elements of a typical cognitive model and few common biases. You would probably have encountered some of the material discussed in the first part of the course in TOK class if you had done IB.

The course structure is mentioned by others.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Carmen speaks quite clearly. She does quite a good job making her class interesting and is helpful both in person and through email.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair, composition is as follows:
Participation  10%
Exam 1          25%
Exam 2          35%  [non-cumulative]
Group project 30% [presentation 15% + written report 15%]

Attendance is taken as part of the participation mark during the last couple of weeks of the term.
~
I received the following:
Participation: unknown.
Exam 1: 67.5 (out of 70)
    - Mean = 52.7 ; S.D. = 10.5
Exam 2: 54 (out of 70)
    - Mean = 54.5 ; S.D. = 10.3
Group project: 70 (out of 100)
    - Mean = 75.4 ; S.D. = 5.8

Result: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is light. There are no assignments besides the group project. However, the group project can be a little bit stressing - make sure that you work well with your group mates.

Exams are generally easy, but the questions are not necessarily straightforward. One two-sided A4 cheat sheet is allowed for both. I did well with two days preparation for the first exam. For the second exam, I only studied on the morning of the exam's day and managed to get away with an average score. Not that hard a course.
